snippet: The European Space Agency lander is sitting in a skewed position on the comet’s surface, compromising some aspects of the $1.75 billion Rosetta mission.
abstract: European Space Agency’s Philae lander, part of $1.75 billion Rosetta mission, bounces three times before making historic landing on surface of Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko; failure of a thruster caused skewed landing position that has partially blocked solar panels necessary for power, but Philae remains in contact with orbiter and has performed its initial set of observations.
lead_paragraph: The European Space Agency lander is sitting in a skewed position on the comet’s surface, compromising some aspects of the $1.75 billion Rosetta mission.

headline.main: Comet Landing Bumpier Than Initially Thought
headline.print_headline: Comet Landing Bumpier Than Initially Thought
